etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in George Puttenham (1529–?1591), writer and literary critic. From philosophy + -ist

definitions: An expert in or student of philosophy; = "philosopher".
An adherent or practitioner of what is held to be erroneous speculation or philosophy; especially an adherent of any rationalist or sceptical philosophical system.

notes.text: In early use applied specifically to the writers and thinkers of the French Enlightenment.
